title: OpenTable names 2 Massachusetts restaurants among the most romantic in the U.S.
author: Autumn Sloboda
bullets: OpenTable named Sorellina in Boston and Pellana Steakhouse in Peabody among the Top 100 Romantic Restaurants in the U.S.
Sorellina, located in Back Bay, features an Italian-Mediterranean menu with seafood and pastas in an intimate setting.
Pellana Steakhouse in Peabody offers a traditional steakhouse experience with prime beef cuts and a comprehensive wine selection.

title: New on Netflix and more: Top streaming picks for February 2026
author: Kevin Slane
bullets: Netflix in February includes 'Ex Machina,' 'Hell or High Water,' and 'You’ve Got Mail' for streaming.
Catherine O'Hara's notable performances to stream include 'A Mighty Wind,' 'Home Alone,' and 'Schitt’s Creek'.
Boston.com staff recommend 'The Pitt' on HBO Max and 'People You Meet on Vacation' on Netflix.

title: What the Patriots need to do in the off-season, according to readers
author: Annie Jonas
bullets: Readers highlighted the need for the Patriots to improve their offensive line after the Super Bowl LX loss.
79% of respondents in a Boston.com poll weren't surprised by the loss, citing offensive line issues.
Suggestions included improving both offensive and defensive lines and acquiring a top wide receiver.

title: Springfield dry sausage plant to close, cutting 190 jobs
author: Beth Treffeisen
bullets: Smithfield Foods will shut down its Springfield, MA dry sausage plant by August, eliminating 190 jobs.
The closure follows a $140,000 EPA settlement over Clean Air Act violations at the Springfield facility.
Employees will receive transition support, and operations will be absorbed by other Smithfield plants in the U.S.

title: What Stefon Diggs said about his Patriots future
author: Khari A. Thompson
bullets: Stefon Diggs plans to stay with the Patriots next season but acknowledges the decision isn't solely his.
Diggs signed a three-year, $69 million contract last offseason, set to last through the 2027 season.
Diggs, who played all games despite ACL surgery, has a court date for assault charges, which he denies.

title: Prosecutor who tried Brian Walshe for murder enters Norfolk DA race
author: Abby Patkin
bullets: Greg Connor, Norfolk County prosecutor, enters the race for district attorney after securing a guilty verdict in the Brian Walshe murder case.
Current Norfolk DA Michael Morrissey announced he will not seek reelection; Connor joins a field of five candidates vying for the position.
Connor plans to address perceived systemic issues in the DA's office while proposing his own initiatives for a more professional and victim-focused approach.

title: Red Sox land Caleb Durbin in six-player trade with Brewers
author: Samantha Genzer
bullets: Red Sox acquire Caleb Durbin from the Brewers in a six-player trade, including three players and a draft pick.
Boston sends pitchers Kyle Harrison and Shane Drohan, plus infielder David Hamilton, to Milwaukee in the exchange.
Durbin, 25, was a finalist for NL Rookie of the Year, hitting .256 with 25 doubles and 18 stolen bases in 2025.

title: Former Jets player charged with killing woman from Framingham
author: Ross Cristantiello
bullets: Former NFL player Darron Lee, 31, charged with murder of Gabriella Perpetuo in Ooltewah, Tennessee.
Perpetuo, 29, was found with signs of trauma and a stab wound; Lee detained at the scene.
Lee held in Hamilton County Jail; first court appearance scheduled for Wednesday.

title: World Cup plans at risk as Foxborough pushes for security funding
author: Beth Treffeisen
bullets: Foxborough may block World Cup matches at Gillette Stadium without $7.7 million for police and safety operations.
Foxborough applied for federal funds but doubts the full amount will be reimbursed in time for the event.
State proposed $20 million for support; only $10 million approved. March 17 deadline set for funding resolution.

title: Marlborough hospital evacuated after ‘Code Black’ shutdown
author: Beth Treffeisen
bullets: UMass Memorial's Marlborough campus evacuated over 70 patients due to heating and water system failures.
A large valve break caused flooding in the boiler system, declaring a ‘Code Black’ and halting ambulance arrivals.
The hospital continues to offer walk-in emergency services but remains closed for inpatient care until further notice.
